ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS SAMURDHI RECIPIENTS IN BELIATTA DIVISIONAL SECRETARYS DIVISION 0216/06 1.

asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Ineternal Administration and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order : (a) Will he submit to this House the names and addresses of the Samurdhi recipients in the Beliatta Divisional Secretariat Division of the Hambantota District, the number of members in each family unit, their monthly income before the receipt of Samurdhi allowance, the value of the Samurdhi allowance and the date on which they received the said allowance for the first time, separately in detail? (b) Will he state, (i) the number of families empowered in the years 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2005 under the empowerment of Samurdhi recipients;

(ii) the name and address, Grama Niladhari Division, the year of empowerment, the name of the Samurdhi Officer of the relevant Division and any other important information regarding each Samurdhi recipient so empowered; and (iii) The subjects under which they have been empowered? (c) If not, why?

SAMURDHI RECIPITENTS IN WEERAKETIYA DIVISIONAL SECRETARYS DIVISION 02176 2.

Asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order (a) Will he submit to this House the names and addresses of the Samurdhi recipients in the Weeraketiya Divisional Secretarys Division of the Hambantota District, the number of members in each family unit, their monthly income before the receipt of Samurdhi allowance, the value of the Samurdhi allowance and the date on which they received the said allowance for the first time, separately in detail? (b) Will he state,- (i) the number of families empowered in the years 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2005 under the empowerment of Samurdhi recipients; (ii) the name and address, Grama Niladhari Division, the year of empowerment, the name of the Samurdhi Officer of the relevant Division and any other important information regarding each Samurdhi recipient so empowered; and (iii) the subjects under which they have been empowered? (c) If not, why?
( ) (The Hon. Jeyaraj Fernandupulle) , , , , . . 0217/06 . . ( ) (The Hon. Vijitha Ranaweera) .

Asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration, and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order : (a) Will he submit to this House the names and addresses of the Samurdhi recipients in the Okawela Divisional Secretarys Division of the Hambantota District, the number of members in each unit, their monthly income before the receipt of Samurdhi allowance, the value of the Samurdhi allowance and the date on which they received the said allowance for the first time, separately in detail? (b) Will he state, (i) the number of families empowered in the years, 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2005 under the empowerment of Samurdhi recipients; (ii) the name and address, Grama Niladhari Division, the year of empowerment, the name of the Samurdhi Officer of the relevant Division and any other important information regarding each Samurdhi recipient so empowered; and
(iii) the subjects under which they have been empowered? (c) If not, why?

, ? () , ? asked the Minister of Healthcare and Nutrition: (a) Is he aware that apart from the Anuradhapura Hospital in the North Central Province, the only hospital that is situated away from Anuradhpura is the Medawachchiya hospit which is on the Jaffna-Mannar main road? (b) Will he take action to develop the Medawachchiya Hospital in order to ease the congestion of patients at the Anuradhapura Hospital? (c) Will he expedite the development activities in the Madawachchiya hospital so as to enable prompt treatment to the soldiers who sustain injuries in the operational areas and to the other residents in the area since the distance from locations such as Jaffna, Mannar, Trincomalee, Horowpathana, Padavi, Sripura colony, Vavuniya, Kebithigollewa, Pulmudi etc. to Medewachchiya is shorter than the distance to the Anuradhapura Hospital? (d) If not, why?

NEW BUILDING COMPLEX OF URBAN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 0630/0 6.

( ) (The Hon. Ranjith Aluvihare) (1) : () ? () ? () ? () , ? , : () ? () ? () ? () , ? Asked the Minister of Urban Development and Sacred Area Development: (a) Is he aware that a function was held recently to lay the foundation stone for the Construction of the new building Complex of the Urban Development Authority? (b) Will he submit to this House with details, the total cost incurred to organize this function? (c) Will he state as to which institution spent such monies? (d) If not why?
) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena Minister of Urban Development and Sacred Area Development ) () . () .
SRI LANKA EMBASSIES IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES 0559/06 7.

asked the Minister of Foreign Affairs: (a) Will he submit this House, (i) the details of the Sri Lankan embassies in Foreign countries; (ii) as to who own the buildings which house these embassies; (iii) whether these offices are maintained on rent or lease basis; and (iv) if so, the amount paid as rent or lease? (b) Will he state, (i) the positions held by the persons employed in the foreign embassies; and (ii) whether the said appointments are on secondment/temporary/contract or permanent basis? (c) Will he submit this House separately the institutions in which they have served in Sri Lanka, the positions held by them, their educational qualifications, their dates of recruitment and the dates of recruitment to the foreign service? (d) If not, why?
( ) (The Hon. Jeyaraj Fernandopulle ) . . () (i) i . I * . (ii) ii . II * . (iii) ii . (iv) ii . () (i) iii . III * (ii) iii . () iii . () .

Asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration, and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order: (a) Will he inform this House,- (i) whether the legislation for protection of Money laundering has been made; (ii) if so, when; and, (iii) the progress made thereon to date? (b) Will he disclose this House, (i) the Acts brought before parliament after the Finance Act. No. 38 of 1971 relating to Finance and Monetary Matters; (ii) the names of such legislations and when they had been brought in; (iii) the efficacy of such laws in operation; (iv) the role that the Financial Intelligence Unit has performed; and, (v) the place where it operates from and to whom it reports? (c) If not, why?
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) . . , 8 (a) (i) , whether the legislation for protection of money laundering has been made; [ ] jack-in-the-box . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) .

() , ? asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Admini-stration, and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order: (a) Will he inform this House,- (i) whether the present Government has received the funds which were approved by the Presi-dent of the United States of America after nam-ing the period 20022003 as Millennium Year, when the present Leader of the Opposi-tion of this country was the Prime Minister; and (ii) if so, what that amount was? (b) Will he state separately, the projects in which the said funds are being spent and the details of the expenditures? (c) Will he admit that, with the peace process of the previous regime, a sum of 450 billion rupees was approved at the Tokyo Aid Group Meeting for Sixty Two (62) projects? (d) Will he state in this House, (i) whether the said sum was invested in projects by the present Government, which came to power by dissolving the Government in power in 2003; and, (ii) if so, the projects in which the said monies were so allocated and the amounts invested in each project separately? (c) If not, why?
( ) (The Hon. Jeyaraj Fernandopulle) , . . ( ) (The Hon. Gamini Jayawickrama Perera) () (i) , 2002-2003 ?- . . ( ) (The Hon. Jeyaraj Fernandopulle) , () (i) . . 2002 . 2002 . (01) .
( ) (The Hon. Jeyaraj Fernandopulle . , Millennium Challenge Account .

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Sir, the Mahinda Chintana was based on certain specific - [Interruption.] . . . . Otherwise you will never be able to go overseas. [Interruption.] See all the UNPers who have come over have the qualifications and know English [Interruption]

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Hon. Speaker, that should be referred to the President as well. He has the intelligence to reslize that when you go overseas, you have to interact in English. So, I guess the President has the ability to realize what the world situation is. My question is, Mahinda Chintana was based on the Premise that promises would be implemented through the Millennium Fund that is going to come in to this country. When the proposals were put forward, they said that the countrys proposals that have come forward do not meet the merit of the Millennium Fund. So, on that basis, please advise on that basis you have put these proposals. They have been rejected. That is why they went to China. The Millennium Fund is not coming.
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) So, tell me from where the money has come.
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Basically Mahinda Chintana has been put forward saying that the money has been given. But the Projects were not accepted. 6 - PL 001833 - (2007/03)
( . . - ) (The Hon. A. D. Susil Premajayantha - Minister of Educa-tion) , . . . . Question ordered to stand down.

(b) Will he state separately, the divisions or names of the officers with their designations in respect of whom such vehicles have been obtained on rent? (c) If not, why

asked the Minister of Public Administration and Home Affairs: (a) Will he inform this House, (i) the number of official quarters meant for public servants, on district basis; (ii) if politicians who are not public servants, are in occupation of such quarters, their number; (iii) who they are? (b) Will he take necessary action to have them ejected from such quarters immediately and to make them available to public servants who are qualified to receive them? (c) Is he aware that, (i) these quarters have been made available to some politicians in the Ampara District and to their friends; (ii) cases have been filed against the public ser-vants to eject them from quarters where they have been residing for 5 years, without taking steps to eject the above mentioned people? (d) If not, why?
) (The Hon. Karu Jayasuriya - Minister of Public Administra-tion and Home Affairs) , * . * :

DEARTH OF TEACHERS IN TAMIL SCHOOLS IN RATNAPURA DISTRICT 0517/06 10. ( . ) ( - . - ) (The Hon. Ranjith Aluvihare - on behalf of The Hon. T. Maheswaran) (2): () (i) ; (ii) , ; (iii) ; ? () ? () , ? : () (i) ,

Asked the Minister of Education: (a) Is he aware that, (i) there is a dearth of teachers in the Tamil schools in Ratnapura District; (ii) although the Sabaragamuwa Provincial Council conducted interviews for the volunteer teachers serving in that area in order to absorb them in to the Teachers service, no decision has been taken in this connection for the last two years; (iii) and no remedial measures have been taken regarding lack of resources in the above said Tamil schools. (b) Will he inform this House, the action that has been taken to remedy the dearth of teachers and lack of resources in these schools along with the action to be taken regarding the volunteer teachers serving in that area? (c) If not why?
AUCTION OF VALUABLE TREES IN PLANTATIONS TAKEN OVER BY COMPANIES 0529/06 11. ( . ) ( - . - ) (The Hon. Ranjith Aluvihare - on behalf of The Hon. T. Maheswaran) (2) : () (i) ; (ii) ; (iii) ;

Asked the Minister of Plantation Industries: (a) Will he inform in this House,- (i) the names and other details of the companies that have taken over the Plantations belonging to the State; (ii) since valuable trees are cut and sold at auctions the reasons for not paying a share of the profit to the workers; (iii) details of those auctions and their values; (iv) the names and the details of the roads used for transporting these trees by heavy vehicles; (v) the reason for not including the details pertain-ing to the cutting and sale of these trees in the Annual Report published by the Estate Man-agement each year; (vi) the action to be taken with respect to roads that are damaged?

(b) Will he state,- (i) the names and other particulars of workers who are affected because of these activities; (ii) the details of profit earned/loss incurred due to this; (iii) the action to be taken by the Government against these companies; (iv) details of trees fell during the last ten years; and, (v) the value of these trees? (c) If not why
) (The Hon. D. M. Jayaratne - Minister of Plantation Indus-tries) , * . * : : Answer tabled : () (i) . .02, , .60, , 03 . .06, , .52, , 10
PRIVILEGE: RUPAVAHINI, ITN, TNL, SWARNAVAHINI, DERANA AND SIRASA TELECAST OF 24TH AND 25TH FEBRUARY, 2007 ( )

( - ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe - Leader of the Opposi-tion) Hon. Speaker, I want to raise a matter concerning a Privilege issue. This is with regard to the reporting made on 24th and 25th February in the telecast of "Rupavahini", "ITN", "TNL", "Swarnavahini", "Derana" and "Sirasa". Before I get onto the subject, I think I should also brief this House on the background to this. , "" . : " (21) (22) . , ." , . , . . , . , it was a garbled one.

, . , . , . . . . , . . . . . , , . ? . . . . . , . - . 12 , 13 . 17 ? , . . , COPE COPE COPE , . 23 . , . . . . . ; . , . . , , . , ; ....." , . . CID , . . , . ; . . , . Erskine May . PUBLICATION OF DEBATES OR PROCEEDINGS

Closely connected with that power is the right of either House to prohibit publication of debates or proceedings. The publication of the debates of either House was in the past repeatedly declared to be a breach of privilege, and especially false and perverted reports of them; .

: CONSTRUCTIVE CONTEMPTS Indignities offered to the House by words spoken of writings pub-lished reflecting on its character or proceedings have been punished by both the Lords and the Commons upon the principle that such acts tend to obstruct the Houses in the performance of their functions by dimin-ishing the respect due to them. : RAISING A COMPLAINT The current procedure of the House of Commons governing the raising by Members .." "Accordingly, a Member who wishes to raise a privilege complaint is required to give written notice . House of Commons , . . . . . ? . ; . . , . . . . , . . . , . , . . . . Ranil Wickremasinghe) , , ( ) 19 . : Protection for publication of reports &c.; published under the authority of Parliament and or publication of copies thereof or extracts therefrom Then, this is protected by law from any criminal or civil charges. So, if any report can be published and it is protected from criminal or civil charges, then it obviously can be used in a debate. I do not think we should go into this issue now. I have also gone through some of the sec-tions of "Parliamentary Practice" by Erskine May. I sug-gest that you call a meeting of the Party Leaders and let us discuss this. ( ) (Mr. Speaker) . NATIONAL CONSTRUCTION ASSOCIATION OF SRI LANKA (INCORPORATION) BILL

. Question put, and agreed to. Bill accordingly read the First time, and ordered to be printed. The Bill stood referred, under Standing Order No. 47(5), to the Minister of Construction and Engineering Services for report.

( - , ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem-Minister of Posts and Telecommu-nication) "Bismillahir Rahmanir Raheem" I move, That the Rule made by the Minister of Posts and Telecom-munication, with the concurrence of the Minister of Finance and Planning under the provisions of the Post Office Ordi-

nance (Chapter 190) to revise the International Postal Rates with effect from 01st October, 2006 and published in the Gazette Extraordinary No. 1464/24 of 29th September, 2006, which was presented on 10.01.2007, be approved. Hon. Speaker, my Predecessor in office, the Hon. D.M. Jayaratne had published in the Gazette the Rule relating to revision of International Postal Rates with effect from 01st of October, 2006. Todays Debate flows from my statutory obligation to place such Rule before the House and at the request of the Party Leaders, we have sub-jected this Notification to a Debate today. Before coming to that subject, I would like to deal initially with the subject of parliamentary privilege that was discussed by Members from both sides of the House. , . . , , , , , , . , , . ; . , , . . . . . , , . . . . . . . , . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) .

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) . . Hon. Speaker, today I am presenting this Rule since my Predecessor has already placed this Rule. Today, we have come before the House to give the background for the revision of foreign postal rates which were brought into effect from the 1st of October, 2006. The last foreign postal revision was on the 22nd of October, 2004. The parity rate of the Special Drawing Rights has since then increased manifold and therefore we have had to, on the advice of the Treasury, revert to this action of revising the foreign postal rates. Here, I must say that my predecessor in office, the Hon. D.M. Jayaratne resisted the pressure from the Treasury to increase the local postal rates in keeping with the policy of this Government not to bring an unnecessary burden on the local customers of the Postal Department. This Department -

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Thank you, Mr. Speaker. While thanking my Predecessor for having taken that timely action to resist some pressure to increase local postal rates, we have come today only to give some rea-sons about revision of the foreign postal rates which really arose as a result of the increase in many different sectors which come into play in determining the Special Drawing Rights which is a unit determined as a payment towards all service providers in the postal sector both here and abroad. There had been an increase in the air transport charges between 2004 and 2007 by 25 per cent. Fuel prices have increased by 20 per cent. Salaries and wages have been increased by 40 per cent. In addition to that, the devaluation of the Sri Lankan Rupee as against the Dollar too contributed towards the necessity for us to im-plement this increase on the foreign postal rates with ef-fect from October, last year. Mr. Speaker, I must say that the Postal Department, has under severe financial strains, been performing a very

important public service. In this regard, yesterday my officials from the Postmaster-Generals Office had a meeting with the Treasury and once again, at the request of the Treasury they had pointed out the need for us to increase the local postal rates. I must say to this House that I as the Minister, as my predecessor did, am not inclined to agree to such a revision, but of course, we may be compelled to consider a revision of commercial users of the Postal Department and charges relating to commercial users. We have found by a recent survey that only 20 per cent of local mail is transacted by the general public whereas almost 80 per cent of the mail transactions today is basically for business purposes by a variety of different business organizations and therefore, it may sometimes be necessary for us to consider some revision without burdening the local public when it comes to postal rates. Having said that, Mr. Speaker, I must also say that the Postal Department needs to be reformed in keeping with the latest trends. In this regard, the large post office net-work that the Postal Department possesses is indeed a big asset which can be turned into better use to meet the latest modern trends in the postal service. During this short period as the Minister in charge of this subject, I have been in charge of the subject for just over a month, within that period, I had the opportunity to meet two different postal administrations, one in the United Arab Emirates, the Emirates Post Authorities as well as the China Post Authorities where I met the Minister in charge of the sub-ject during the recent State visit to China along with His Excellency the President. I found that both the China Post and the Emirates Post have modernized their postal de-partments to such an extent that there is a variety of dif-ferent value added services offered by the Postal Depart-ments in those countries. They have also converted the Government-owned entity into an independent authority in order to conduct the business of postal administration.
. Whereupon MR. SPEAKER left the Chair and MR. DEPUTY SPEAKER (THE HON. GITANJANA GUNAWARDENA ) took the Chair.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Mr. Deputy Speaker, I was referring to the necessary reforms that we may have to introduce in order to im-prove the services the Postal Department can offer and as I mentioned earlier, we do possess a very fine network of post offices.
( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) , it is non-existent. . -
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) I think you can get some relief from the fact that my Deputy Minister is a senior trade unionist from the estate sector. ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) I know that.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) That is one of his interests and in fact he has brought it to our notice. ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) At least if you can get the letters delivered division by division, even that is something.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) There are certain proposals that we would like to discuss.
( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) I must tell you that it is in dire straits. Sometimes peo-ple who are called for interviews get the letters one month later.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Indeed. Actually what I find is, among the customer-base of the Postal Department, among the local public and in sectors like the estate sector, employees are compelled to use this service since they come from the lower strata. Because now with the modern advances in transmission of letters through other means like e-mails and other facilities the local public who use the traditional postal service to convey messages to their kith and kin have decreased in a large way. ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) People in the urban area resort to-

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) They resort to other means. And, therefore - ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) But these people depend entirely on this. ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) It is therefore our duty to see that a better service is given to the rural and backward sectors and particularly to the estate sector, and its requirements have been brought to my notice and to the notice of the authorities by the Hon. Deputy Minister. I am sure he will also say a few words on the subject. Now let me move on to another important subject which has been raised both by my Friends, the Hon. Thurairetnasingam, the Member representing the Trinco-malee District and also this morning by the Hon. Ee-laventhan, the Member for the Jaffna District who have been very concerned about the large number of parcel post articles which remain undelivered in the Trinco-malee District. I will say a few words in Tamil in that regard. , , . . . , , , . , , . -9 , , . , .

. That relates to Class 1 pro-motions that are given according to the Cabinet ap-proval we got in 1992. Actually, Mr. Deputy Speaker, both categories, the clerical and the post master category of staff were amalgamated into one. The expected ratio that was agreed according to the Cabinet decision is one to five: clerical one to post masters five. This was based on the actual number of staff that was then existing in the postal sector. But of the 244 Class 1 promotions, 136 have already been given. This, unfortunately, had hap-pened before I became aware of this situation. Since there is a protest by the clerical union stating that some injus-tice had been caused to them, we are now looking into this matter. This is being examined by the Postal Depart-ment and we would try to rectify any discrepancy that may have occurred in this regard at the time the balance promotions are given. I would like to give this assurance to Mr. Ariyanethran who brought this to my notice this morning. Together with that, the Hon. Hemakumara Nanayak-kara brought to my attention this morning another issue relating to telegram forms being unavailable in many post offices. I must say that the telegram service is owned and managed by the Sri Lanka Telecom and the Department of Posts provides only an agency service. However, telegram forms which are printed and supplied by the Sri Lanka Telecom to the Department of Posts will be available from today. Since there had been some short supply, the Sri Lanka Telecom stores has now printed a new stock and that will be ready for distribution to post offices and sub-post offices from today. With that, I be-lieve the shortage of telegram forms in the post offices will be brought to an end. Together with that, Mr. Deputy Speaker, I must also say that a new system is being introduced for the benefit of all Parliamentarians. There is a new system of sending telegrams by the Hon. Members of Parliament which has been brought into existence. Members of Parliament could send telegrams over the telephone to the Sri Lanka Telecom Regional Telecom Engineer's Office Phone

Room and the Sri Lanka Telecom staff will transmit these telegrams to recipients through the post office and sub-post office network of our department. This is another new service that we have initiated for the benefit of Par-liamentarians. Having said that, Mr. Deputy Speaker, since most of our time had been taken up by the Hon. Members from both sides talking about issues of Privilege that were raised in the morning, I have hardly any time to talk about the rest of the matters that I wanted to bring to your notice. But, there is one other matter that I would like to raise. ( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Minister, I think it is important that we intro-duce ICTA, information technology into the post of-fices as soon as possible because that will facilitate e-mail, internet and other facilities and even sending tele-grams would be much easier. So, I think you should try to address that issue as an urgent matter. ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Yes, it is a very important subject. In fact, the Postal Department has introduced this to some of the post of-fices and around 40 post offices today are having these facilities. But we would like to expand it further, at least to the existing graded post offices initially and thereafter to the sub-post office network. This is a matter which we would have to discuss with some funding agencies in order to see that we could expand this service, which is an essential service today growing with the latest technol-ogy. Since I am also the Minister in charge of telecom-munication, it is a subject which I may have to facilitate as soon as possible. Having said that, Mr. Deputy Speaker, there is one other subject relating to lack of high denomination revenue stamps which has been brought to my notice following a discussion the Hon. Karu Jayasuriya, the Minister of Pub-lic Administration had with the Colombo Law Society a few days ago. I read in one of the newspapers that the Colombo Law Society has brought to his notice and also to the Registrar General's Office that high denomination revenue stamps are in short supply. This is in fact true and when I discussed this matter with the Post Master General and his authorities, I was informed that unfortu-nately a tender that was called to print these high denomi-nation stamps was cancelled due to some protests that had been made. The reasons as to why it happened had been brought to the notice of the Treasury authorities and it was finally agreed by the Cabinet to call for tenders once again and for these stamps to be printed overseas since the Government Printer was not willing to undertake the printing of high valued revenue stamps. I must say that

this shortage should come to an end within the next three months, hopefully. In the meantime if the Registrar Gen-eral's Department and the Colombo Law Society want, we can suggest certain alternative methods of trying to use imprints for purposes of affixing stamps onto deeds and other documents or otherwise to even deposit monies in a bank and to affix the receipt as a substitute measure to overcome this difficulty for the next three months. In the meantime I must also say that a matter has been brought to the notice of the Treasury, that the Postal De-partment does not get any revenue out of the high valued revenue stamps that we print and distribute. This entire revenue is credited to the Inland Revenue Department and a request has been made by us to the Treasury that at least 7.5 per cent of the value of revenue stamps for printing and selling, an operational cost - 5 per cent being selling cost and 2.5 per cent being printing cost - must be cred-ited to our account so that we can show a better balance sheet to Parliament at least during the next Budget. There are other means through which we can certainly improve the quality of the Postal Service in this country and having observed how modern value added services are being offered by advanced countries, particularly on my recent visits to United Arab Emirates and China - the Emirates Post and the China Post - I feel that there are different value added services that we too could offer. Already we are offering some of these services. There is a variety of other different services we could expand on and definitely the Postal Department will in due course, embark on these services in order to make it a viable and efficient service. I am sure I could discuss those reforms with the trade unions as well as with the Treasury Offi-cials in time to come and see that the Postal Department which has a very long history in this country is improved. It came into being during the colonial times in the 19th Century and ever since then it has been performing a very valuable and essential service to the customers. Now with the changing trends in the modern telecommunication industry, the services of the postal department in certain sectors have become somewhat obsolete and therefore we have to try and move on to different sectors and value added services in order to remain competitive. I must as-sure this House that the Postal Department is on the path to recovery using these different value added services. Thank you very much. [.. 11.34] . ( . ) (The Hon. M. Joseph Michael Perera) , . . . . , .

- His Excellency the Ambassador, who is noted for his diplomatic language and also for his measured language - ( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, it would help if you keep to the subject in debate. . . ( . . ) (The Hon. M. K. Eelaventhan) Yes. I will conclude, Sir. I was just touching on the very crucial issue affecting the very existence of Tamils here. I just touched on it and I will deal with the subject in debate.

The statement emanating from the American Ambassador clearly vindicates the position of the Tigers that they are a responsible group and they were not indulging in senseless killings of any people especially the mighty diplomats. That is one important point. I see another important point as regards the transfer of judges, especially Ms. Srinithi Nanthasekaran and also Mr. Manikkavasagar Ganesaraja who had been suddenly, overnight, transferred interfering with the independent judiciary and separation of powers which we learn is something of a golden rule. But now we live to see; we have to re-learn and unlearn many things in life. This cannot go on forever. Now I will deal with the subject as regards the Rule under the Post Office Ordinance. Our Friend and my worthy Friend, the Hon. Hakeem gives me an assurance saying, Eelaventhan do not worry. Everything is being rectified as regards what is happening in the Trincomalee Post Office. But with due respect to the Minister, the Hon. Hakeem, I would like to mention that before he left for China he did give an assurance or he virtually commanded the Post Office that before he returns from China everything should be in normal order. But unfortunately for the Tamils, because they are always an affected people, our friend Thamilselvan had said 'Tigers warn of bloodbath if things are not going to be normal. Things are not normal in Trincomalee. I have got enough information. Whatever the Minister may say, I have got enough information to prove it. Am I to believe the Hon. Minister or am I to believe the UC Member, Mr. Arudchelvam? I prefer to believe the Hon. Minister. But things are not as has been presented by the Hon. Minister. Mr. Arudchelvam gives me a call in the morning and says something different. , -9 . '' . . , , . , , , . . , , , . . . , , . , . , . . ; . . , . . , , , , , ,

( The Hon. Neomal Perera - Deputy Minister of Fisheries ) , . , . . 37,000 . 37,000 outboard motor 16,500, 17,000 . , , FRP . , , , , , . . , surcharge . Harbour - - surcharge brokering companies . ; . , - compensation package - . . , compensation package , credit . . . .

. . , , . . . . . 2006 17 , . . , . 2007 27 Harbour . . Harbour . . ; . , Harbour . . ; . , , . . . . , . , . . ; Economic Zone 175 . , , . . . Do not act like irresponsible politicians. I hope that hereafter, whatever the package we are going to give, they would not find out about it early, then bring it forward and say that it is because of them that the Government is introducing it. So, Hon. Deputy Speaker, I am - . . ( . . ) (The Hon. M. K. Eelaventhan) Sir, I rise to a point of Order. Are you talking about all the fishermen? Are you saying that under that pretext they are carrying arms? Whether they be Sinhala or Tamil fishermen, are they going to be starved to death?
( ) The Hon. Neomal Perera ) No, they will not be starved to death.
. . ( . . ) (The Hon. M. K. Eelaventhan) Now tell me. Already, people are dying. They are dying in Batticoloa; they are dying in Trincomlaee. Are you denying it?
( ) The Hon. Neomal Perera ) We are talking about the zone that is targeted to be attacked and under high security.
. . ( . . ) (The Hon. M. K. Eelaventhan) I know. Everything is done under the name of security.
( ) The Hon. Neomal Perera ) Only in high security areas that are under threat, there are restrictions. Why is the LTTE abducting poor fishermen?

. . ( . . ) (The Hon. M. K. Eelaventhan) The Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Karunanidhi said, We will enter into your warfront. ( ) (The Hon. Neomal Perera) Therefore, Sir, we have to take this measure. Similarly, we will look after them because we see it as a temporary move. We see that at the end of the day, there would be an end to the war. We know that this has to be negotiated. We all agree. But, we cannot be sitting ducks for LTTE firing. - [Interruption.] So, this is a very good move to prevent any attacks in the future on the innocent citizens of this country, including the Tamil citizens who are living in Colombo. Economically, they also will be deprived of their opportunities if there is an attack on the harbour or any government institution because they are living like brothers and sisters of one family in Colombo. Therefore, Sir, I hope this is a good measure to prevent the catastrophes we have faced due to not taking decisions at the right moment - [Interruption.] There are a lot of packages that have been introduced, which were never introduced before in the history of the fisheries industry of this country. So, give us time, give us the opportunity; give the

Minister the opportunity to work it out and see that all the fishermen in this country would benefit. We will also make sure that this country would actually overtake the fisheries industry in countries of the South-East Asian Region such as Japan, Taiwan and Thailand. Just give us time. We are not asking for decades. Give us a few years, two or three years and we will see that it is implemented. Thank you very much, Mr. Deputy Speaker.
